question.answerText: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage  Since the beginning of 2022, Government has supported the delivery of 35,163 new social homes across thousands of individual projects funded through build, acquisition and leasing programmes.  Building on progress made to date the new Housing Plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities aims to deliver 300,000 new homes in the period to 2030, including 72,000 social homes and 90,000 starter home supports. The Plan seeks to significantly scale-up delivery of new build social homes over the coming years, increasing from an average of 8,000 or so homes a year at present to an average of 12,000 per year.  In 2025, Government has allocated almost €7.5 billion in capital investment for Housing, inclusive of Land Development Agency investment and Housing Finance Agency (HFA) lending. The 2025 capital funding is supplemented by €1.93 billion in current funding to address housing needs.  This record level of investment for the delivery of housing will continue in 2026 with €5.2bn in Exchequer capital funding complemented by investment through the Land Development Agency (LDA) and lending from the Housing Finance Agency (HFA), bringing the total capital funding for housing in 2026 to over €9 billion.  The Government remains committed to increasing social housing delivery and a key focus of the social housing programme is to increase the number of new-build homes.  To incentivise local authorities to deliver more ‘own build’ projects, a new performance fund will be established. Where a local authority exceeds their ‘own build’ target they will receive additional discretionary funding for the delivery of community and placemaking initiatives and projects. In addition, ring-fenced 'new-build' housing delivery teams in each local authority dedicated to own build new social and affordable housing delivery will be fully funded by my Department through reimbursement to local authorities on a performance pay basis.  Delivering Homes, Building Communities will further support additional social housing delivery by mandating the use of standard house layouts and specifications as part of the new approval process and facilitate the use of Modern Methods of Construction (MMC) through a standardised design approach. To further promote the delivery of social housing I will embed the use of a Design and Build contract approach in all local authorities and the AHB sector in order to expedite the delivery of social housing.  Additionally, the new ‘single approval’ process for all new build social housing projects up to a value of €200m will support local authorities to streamline processes and encourage delivery of larger new build social housing developments.  Furthermore, the Land Acquisition Fund will be reformed, streamlined and expanded to ensure it is fit for purpose and can support the level of ambition in the Plan. To this end, the fund will also be increased from the current €239m to at least €500m.  The newly established Housing Activation Office (HAO) will identify and seek to address barriers to the delivery of public infrastructure projects required to enable housing development, through the alignment of funding; and co-ordination of infrastructure providers.  In addition to these measures, Government will establish a revamped contractor-led renewal programme focused on tackling dereliction and vacancy.  In 2025, my Department has provided €375 million to support a second-hand acquisitions programme. The programme supports priority categories of need, including exits from homeless services, tenancy sustainment (tenant in situ), people with a disability and older persons requiring urgent housing responses, and Buy and Renew acquisitions tackling vacancy. €50 million of this funding was ring fenced to target acquisitions that support households, primarily larger families with children, to exit long-term emergency accommodation arrangements.  I expect the 2026 programme to maintain support for the priority categories and individual local authority allocations, will be agreed and notified to local authorities early next year.  My Department publishes comprehensive programme-level statistics on a quarterly basis on social and affordable housing delivery activity by local authorities and Approved Housing Bodies (AHBs) in each local authority. This data is available to the end of Q2 2025 and is published on the statistics page of my Department’s website (www.gov.ie/en/collection/6060e-overall-social-housing-provision/).  These figures show that from the beginning of 2020 to the end of Q2 2025, over 35,000 new homes have been delivered under social housing build programmes.  In the first six months of 2025, 1,804 new build social homes were delivered. This is an increase of almost 54% on the same period in 2024 (1,174).  The latest Construction Status Report shows that the social housing pipeline is strong and continues to grow with 11,557 social homes currently onsite with an additional 15,127 homes at design and tender stage. In Quarter 2 2025, 141 new construction schemes (2,478 homes) were added to the pipeline. The most recent publication was for Quarter 2 2025. All CSRs are available at the following link: www.gov.ie/en/collection/cb885-social-housing-construction-projects-status-reports/
question.showAs: 504. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage the key measures taken to expand social housing provision during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73534/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage  I propose to take Questions Nos. 505 and 510 together.  The Government’s new housing plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities 2025-2030, sets out a broad range of measures that will accelerate new homes delivery and provide affordable housing supports, thereby assisting first time buyers and renters all over the country.  The new plan prioritises deliverability, removing structural barriers to homebuilding by unlocking land, reforming planning, delivering infrastructure and creating conditions for investment.  A key component of this plan, the new Starter Homes Programme, will deliver an average of 15,000 affordable housing supports annually to 2030, while at the same time having a keen focus on vacancy and dereliction.  The Plan supports homeownership and secure rental —while revitalising villages, towns and cities.  In particular, the plan provides for an expanded remit for the Land Development Agency, extends the First Home and Help to Buy Schemes to 2030 and expands the local authority delivered starter homes for purchase programme, which will see an increase in affordable homes for purchase nationwide.  It also creates a new support for those creating Living over the Shop homes.  Since 2021, Government has introduced several schemes to help first time home seekers to buy or rent homes, with close to 16,900 affordable housing supports having been provided via these measures, nationwide.  My Department proactively engages with the housing delivery partners, on a regular basis, to monitor and support their delivery of affordable housing.  Scheme criteria and support levels for affordable purchase schemes are kept under regular review, taking account of developments in the housing market. I will continue engaging with all delivery partners, to ensure that the Starter Homes Programme delivers a strong pipeline of affordable housing supports, over the lifetime of the plan.

question.answerText: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage  Working to end dereliction and vacancy is a key priority in the Government's new housing plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities. The Plan will ensure that the activities and resources used to address vacancy and dereliction are co-ordinated, and that legislative powers are used proactively to work to bring dereliction and vacancy to an end.  The range of initiatives and funding mechanisms introduced in recent years are set out in the Vacant Homes Action Plan and they are successfully reducing the levels of vacancy and dereliction right across the country.  A key measure is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant, introduced in July 2022. The grant provides up to €70,000 for the refurbishment of vacant and derelict properties for occupation as a principal private residence and for properties which will be made available for rent. There has been significant interest in the grant since its launch, with over 15,600 applications made to local authorities to date and over €230 million of grant funding paid out across the country.  This week I announced a new enhanced support package of up to €140,000 to bring vacant ‘above shop’ space in our cities, towns and villages into use as homes, which will be made available in Q1 next year.  This year, my Department has been engaging with the national statistical institute, the Central Statistics Office, which has recently developed a new statistical release on residential vacancy.  The release, published in September, provides information on the extent of residential vacancy in 2022 and 2023, using ESB data on residential electricity consumption, with future regular publications planned. In the release, the CSO note a national vacancy rate of 3.3% at the end of 2023, down from 3.6% at the end of 2022. Local authority and local electoral level breakdowns are also included.  The CPO Activation Programme, launched in 2023, requires local authorities to take a proactive, systematic approach to identifying and activating vacant and derelict properties. It includes use of their compulsory purchase powers under the Derelict Sites Act and the Housing Act, when engagement with the owners of these properties is not successful in bringing them back into use.  In October, my Department published data for 2023 and 2024 on the CPO Activation Programme on its website, which includes the number of properties that entered the Programme, the number of compulsory purchase/acquisitions commenced and the number of compulsory purchase/acquisitions completed per local authority. This data can be accessed at the following link: assets.gov.ie/static/documents/bdfef028/CPO_Activation_Programme_-_LA_use_of_CPO_powers.pdf  Call 3 of the Urban Regeneration and Development Fund (URDF), as well as Social Housing Investment Programme funding, is able to provide the finance required to compulsorily acquire properties in support of the local authority’s wider CPO Activation Programme targets. To date, over 1,370 properties have now been approved for local authority's URDF Call 3 programmes, with an estimated residential yield of over 5,600 homes.  Delivering Homes, Building Communities reinforces and expands the range of measures being implemented by Government to work to end dereliction and long term vacancy.  As well as the new Above the Shop Grant and other measures, a new Derelict Property Tax will be introduced, to be administered and collected by the Revenue Commissioners, to bring derelict properties back into use.  Under the Living City Initiative, a tax incentive scheme to encourage people to live in ‘special regeneration areas’, tax relief can be claimed for money spent on refurbishing or converting residential or commercial buildings. The aim of the initiative is to bring back life into the heart of the relevant cities and towns by encouraging people to convert suitable properties. Budget 2026 extended the Living City Initiative to 2030, and expanded it to include residential properties built before 1975 and the towns of Athlone, Drogheda, Dundalk, Letterkenny and Sligo.  I firmly believe the commitment Government has made to addressing vacancy and dereliction and the actions under Delivering Homes, Building Communities will play a vital role in delivering homes across the country.
question.showAs: 507. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage the key measures taken to tackle vacancy and dereliction during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73537/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage  Affordability and the chance to own a home is at the heart of Government’s housing policy, as embodied within the new housing plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities 2025 – 2030. The plan reinforces and expands the range of existing measures being implemented by Government to tackle the issues of supply and affordability, thereby supporting the increased provision of new homes to purchase and rent.  Cost Rental is a key element of the Government's strategy to improve affordability in the rental sector and to provide secure, long-term homes for moderate-income households above the income limits for social housing. The core principle is that rents cover the development, management, and maintenance costs of the homes, so that their long-term future is secure, without rents being subject to the pressures of the open market.  As rents depend on actual delivery costs, various Cost Rental homes will have different degrees of affordability for the range of potential applicants. My Department is supporting the delivery of homes at a range of cost and rent levels, depending on factors like location and the size or type of home, and affordability is always a key consideration. By providing significant capital funding, my Department helps to drive down the rents that must be paid by tenants. This funding comes as low-cost loans, capital grants, and State investment. All supported Cost Rental projects must achieve starting rents that are at least 25% (and often significantly more) below comparable local market levels.  The 2025 Programme for Government includes a commitment to target Cost Rental homes at key local workers, and my Department is working to explore all options for achieving this.  In the meantime, we are working to implement certain changes which were made to Part 3 of the Affordable Housing Act 2021 late last year. The Housing (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2024 included new provisions related to the Cost Rental sector which are likely to improve access for certain cohorts.  On 2 July this year I made the Affordable Housing Act 2021 (Cost Rental Allocation Plan) Regulations 2025. These Regulations allow for Cost Rental landlords to employ Allocation Plans which may prioritise particular homes for those with a link to an area though residence, employment, or children’s education. This will support people to live and work in their local area.  The Programme for Government also includes a commitment to introduce a cost rental version of the Repair and Lease scheme on a pilot basis. This is aimed both at tackling vacancy and dereliction and providing affordable housing. The new housing plan contains a commitment to develop a pathfinder project for an affordable rental version of the repair and lease scheme and my Department is working with Local Authorities to develop a viable scheme to achieve these aims.  My Department continues to review the operation of the Cost Rental housing tenure.
question.showAs: 508. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage the key measures taken to expand cost rental during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73538/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage  Government is acutely aware of the viability gap which has emerged between the cost of delivering apartment developments and their market price and has taken a range of measures to incentivise development in this critically important area.  Measures taken in 2025 include: enabling the extension of un-commenced residential planning permissions nearing the end of their duration; rental regulation reforms including measures to boost investment in new apartments; a fourth call for the Croí Cónaithe Cities scheme which aims to bridge the viability gap for new apartments for sale; new apartment guidelines with greater flexibility vis-à-vis the size and mix of apartments; Budget 2026 taxation measures aimed at stimulating the supply of new apartments including a reduced VAT rate on the sale of new apartments and an enhanced Corporation Tax deduction for apartment construction costs.  Taken together, these measures have the potential to result in significant savings in the range of €88,000 to €160,000 per unit for new apartment developments.  The focus for 2026 will be on the implementation of these measures and closely monitoring apartment investment, planning and commencement activity to inform ongoing policy consideration.

The Government’s new housing plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities 2025-2030, sets out a broad range of measures that will accelerate new homes delivery and provide affordable housing supports, thereby assisting first time buyers and renters all over the country.  The new plan prioritises deliverability, removing structural barriers to homebuilding by unlocking land, reforming planning, delivering infrastructure and creating conditions for investment. question.answerText: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage  The Government is focused on increasing the national housing stock and ensuring a suitable range of housing is available to all. Activating housing supply is multifaceted, requiring a concerted effort across a number of policy areas and a range of measures were taken in 2025 to boost overall housing supply.  The Planning and Development Act 2024 represents the most comprehensive review of planning since 2000 and a detailed plan for the implementation of the Act was published in March 2025. The first phase of commencements has provided for the establishment of An Coimisiún Pleanála and introduced provisions for reformed planning judicial review. New tools such as Urban Development Zones and Urban and Priority Area Plans will support faster, more responsive delivery of housing and infrastructure, where it is needed most.  The Planning and Development (Amendment) Bill 2025 was approved, published and enacted before the summer recess to deal with expiring planning permissions and to encourage activation of housing, while the new Housing Activation Office will work to address barriers to the delivery of infrastructure projects needed to enable housing development.  The revised National Planning Framework (NPF) approved in April is a major step forward, and will help increase capacity and accelerate home building across the country. In July, I issued Guidelines instructing local authorities to update housing targets in line with the revised NPF. The new Guidelines set out the need to plan for approximately 55,000 additional households per annum on average to 2040, enabling zoning for a total of 83,000 units per annum.  In June, Government also agreed to amend the rent pressure zone framework, which will help stimulate increased development of apartments over the longer-term.  A fourth call for expressions of interest under the Croí Cónaithe Cities scheme was issued over the summer with submitted schemes now currently being assessed. The scheme will help activate the thousands of planning permissions for apartments in our cities. Furthermore, an enhanced Land Development Agency is working to deliver more private housing as well as social, affordable and cost rental homes.  The delivery of housing is at the centre of the updated National Development Plan, published in July, which provides for unprecedented levels of investment for housing and water infrastructure with overall investment of €40.5bn provided for housing and related water services to 2030. Furthermore, a record level of investment is being provided for the delivery of housing in 2026 with overall capital funding of over €9 billion announced in Budget 2026.  Government also announced in Budget 2026 reduced VAT on sale of apartments from 13.5% to 9%, Enhanced Corporation Tax Deductions on Construction Expenses to improve the viability of apartment building, and a Corporation Tax Exemption for Cost Rental Income to encourage delivery and increase viability of cost rental units.  The Government’s new plan Delivering Homes, Building Communities was published on 13 November 2025. The implementation of the actions set out in the plan, will see the delivery of 300,000 new homes over its lifetime, including 72,000 social homes, and provide 90,000 affordable supports to help people who are struggling to have a home of their own.  Pillar 1 of the new plan focuses on activating the supply of 300,000 homes. This will be achieved through a range of actions aimed at activating more land, providing more housing-related infrastructure, securing more development finance for home building, addressing viability challenges, particularly in apartment delivery, increasing the adoption of Modern Methods of Construction, improving labour skills in the residential construction sector, and working towards ending dereliction and vacancy.  These actions will be progressed in 2026 and further information is available at the following link:  www.gov.ie/en/department-of-housing-local-government-and-heritage/publications/enabling-more-housing/#activating-supply
question.showAs: 513. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage the key measures taken to boost overall housing supply during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73543/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Justice, Home Affairs and Migration  My Department is actively contributing to a programme of insurance reform which is being implemented on a whole-of-government basis.  There are clear signs that the market is responding to the Government’s actions, with insurers moving into previously challenging areas such as childcare, leisure activities and sports. We have also seen that incumbent providers are expanding their product offerings into areas such as SMEs, hospitality, agriculture, and energy, and there has been renewed international interest in Ireland as an insurance destination.  The Occupiers Liability Act 1995 was amended in 2023 with a view to making insurance more affordable for consumers, businesses and community groups. The amendments to the Act:   inserted into primary law a number of recent court decisions which rebalance the duty of care owed by occupiers to visitors and recreational users;   changed the standard to clarify that when the occupier of a property has acted with reckless disregard for a visitor or customer, it is the standard of reckless disregard rather than reasonable grounds which should apply in relation to any consideration of liability;   limited the circumstances in which a court can impose liability on the occupier of a premises where a person has entered onto premises for the purpose of committing an offence; and  allowed for a broader range of scenarios where it can be shown that a visitor or customer has voluntarily assumed a risk resulting in harm.  The amendments contained in the Act were designed to strike the right balance between ensuring businesses, community groups and organisers of events fulfil their duty of care responsibilities, while also acknowledging the importance of personal responsibility of visitors, recreational users and trespassers. The impact of these changes will be assessed over time.  As the Deputy will be aware, the first iteration of the Personal Injury Guidelines came into effect in April 2021 and have had a clear and significant cost saving impact since their introduction. On the 17 September, as required by section 7 of the Judicial Council Act 2019, I laid revised personal injury guidelines before the Houses of the Oireachtas. Prior to the laying of the documents, I consulted Ministerial colleagues and the Attorney General in relation to the proposed increase in award amounts contained in the Judicial Council’s proposals.  While there were concerns that any delay in the adoption of new guidelines could lead to the courts being invited to depart from the guidelines and to seek higher awards reflecting the effect of inflation, to be applied at the discretion of the Court, I was also conscious of concerns raised in relation to potential inflationary pressures. Therefore, it is my intention not to bring a Resolution before the Houses seeking the approval of the guidelines at this time. In effect, this means that the amended Guidelines cannot come into effect and the existing Guidelines will remain in place.  In addition, I have received Government approval to draft a general scheme of a Bill to amend the Judicial Council Act 2019 to make reviews of the Personal Injuries Guidelines more comprehensive and transparent. I intend to bring the General Scheme of the Bill to Government early in the New Year, after which it will be referred for Pre-Legislative Scrutiny.  The Government is conscious that further work needs to be done to compel insurance companies to lower their premia, a point that has been frequently made by the Taoiseach, Tánaiste and Minister of State Robert Troy, who has published a new Action Plan for Insurance Reform.  I am also conscious of the impact legal costs can have on insurance premia. I have received government approval to draft a Civil Reform Bill which among other matters will see the monetary jurisdiction of the District Court increase from €15,000 to €20,000 while in the Circuit Court it will increase from €75,000 to €100,000. The lower limit for personal injury cases in the Circuit Court will also increase from €60,000 to €100,000. These changes will result in a higher proportion of civil actions being heard in the District and Circuit Courts, leading to lower legal costs for all parties involved
question.showAs: 564. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Justice, Home Affairs and Migration the key measures taken under the remit of his Department to control insurance costs during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73548/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Health  I propose to take Questions Nos. 670 and 671 together.  It is recognised that endometriosis is a significant health issue for women in Ireland today and the HSE acknowledges that it is a difficult condition to diagnose and treat because of the variation of presentations which can impact the physical and mental wellbeing of patients. Endometriosis is a chronic disease with high recurrence rates, for which there is no definitive cure.  On 18 October I launched the National Framework for the management of Endometriosis. The Framework sets out for the first time in Ireland a defined clinical pathway for women with endometriosis, which spans primary to secondary care to specialist complex care in tertiary settings.  Most women experiencing signs and symptoms of endometriosis present to their local GP in the community. In line with clinical guidelines, GPs are encouraged to initiate treatment for suspected endometriosis and may refer women with suspected endometriosis to general gynaecology services in their local hospital.  Regional Specialist Centres for moderate cases have been established in the Rotunda, the Coombe, and Limerick, with clinics under further development in Galway and the National Maternity Hospital.  Two supra-regional specialist centres, in Tallaght and Cork, have been established for the management of complex endometriosis cases.  All endometriosis sites are operational and taking referrals. Treatment including surgical intervention is being provided across the network.  Additional funding has been provided this year to expand these services through the recruitment of more personnel to provide multidisciplinary care at both supra-regional and regional level.  The Framework was officially published in October of this year. Funding of over €5 million has already been invested in specialist endometriosis services since 2021. In addition, endometriosis surgeries have been and continue to be performed in other acute gynaecology services.  The HSE has carried out an analysis of the short term and medium-term requirements to build adequate capacity, improve clinical pathways and increase expertise within our endometriosis services. The HSE’s budget for 2026 will be €27.4 billion, an increase of 6.2% on 2025. This investment will enable expansion and improvement in our health services, including endometriosis.  The Endometriosis Surgery Abroad Interim Scheme commenced from the 18 October and will operate in addition to the existing treatment abroad pathways, including the EU Treatment Abroad Scheme, the EU Cross Border Directive and Northern Ireland Planned Healthcare Schemes. The interim scheme will cover costs for the transport abroad and for healthcare provided, paid directly to the hospital.  Where a person accesses private healthcare in Ireland there is no facility for the cost of that care to be reimbursed by the public health system.
question.showAs: 670. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Health if she will address the concerns regarding the treatment of women with endometriosis raised in correspondence (details supplied); and if she will make a statement on the matter. [73493/25]

question.showAs: 671. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Health if she will address the request for reimbursement of costs incurred for endometriosis treatment raised in correspondence (details supplied); and if she will make a statement on the matter. [73494/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science  As I'm sure the Deputy is aware, the breath and scope of the Higher Education sector across Ireland is significant, as too is the work of my Department in supporting the sector. Consequently I will focus my response on key highlights from 2025 and high level priorities for 2026.   Measures taken in 2025 to support the Higher Education sector. Supporting Students and Families:   • I secured a €500 reduction in the student contribution fee – the first permanent reduction since free fees were introduced in 1995. Apprentices in higher education will also see an up to 17% cut to their contribution, applied on a pro-rata basis.  • More families will qualify for student grants - the income threshold to receive a SUSI student contribution grant will rise to €120,000 – the highest ever. This change could benefit thousands of additional undergraduate students.  • 30,000 students to get more support when living or travelling away from home - from September 2026, SUSI non-adjacent payments will rise by €200–€430, with a pro-rata increase this academic year - helping students who live 30km or more from their college campus with the cost of rent, travel, and day-to-day living.  • Postgraduate support boosted - the SUSI postgraduate fee contribution grant is rising from €4,000 to €4,500, backed by a €1 million investment.   Supporting Teaching and Learning in Higher Education   • I am supporting the enhancement of teaching and learning in Higher Education through the Strategic Alignment of Teaching and Learning Enhancement (SATLE) funding. Higher education institutions collectively received €5 million in SATLE funding in the 2024/25 academic year. This is used to fund initiatives in the areas of digital transformation, Education for Sustainable Development and academic integrity.  • I am also supporting the HEA in their policy work regarding teaching and learning, including the forthcoming national policy framework on generative AI, due to be published in the coming weeks.  • In November, my department held a consultation with the further and higher education sector and other stakeholders which explored the potential for greater embedding of creativity across third level education and research.   Continued Support for the Technological Sector:   • Investment of €65.8m over three years for the Technological sector and specialist colleges.  • On foot of intensive work by my Department, I have now secured the introduction of Professorship grades into the Technological University sector . The grade will see the approval for 50 professors in technological universities and the technology sector, with an initial rollout of 25 across the system through the Targeted Enhancement Fund. My Department will continue to engage with colleagues on this matter and will consult with key stakeholders on the introduction of this new grade to Technological Universities.   Expanding Access to key skills areas - Health Workforce Planning:   • In the area of Health Workforce Planning, a new dentistry programme and two new pharmacy programmes successfully commenced in September.  • An additional pharmacy programme, two veterinary programmes and new medicine programme are on the CAO for 2026, and on track to take in students.  • An expansion of existing nursing programmes has been approved and communicated to HEIs with this expansion due to come on stream in 2026.  • An additional 300 Health and Social Care Professional places commenced in September as planned and further places to be made available in 2026.   Support for learners to upskill in key priority areas through Springboard+   • Springboard+ 2025 launched in May 2025 provides 7,719 places on 249 courses, including 26 micro-credentials providing 752 places for the 2025/2026 academic year. Funding for Springboard+ in the 2025 financial year is secured from the National Training Fund (NTF), with €34.438 million allocated.  • The Micro-Credentials Learner Fee Subsidy was launched in March 2024 to subsidise fees for 13,763 learners across 650 micro-credential courses, with an 80% subsidy rate for key priority areas including artificial intelligence, cyber security and ICT (and 50% for other courses). The scheme is running until the end of the 2025/2026 academic year and learners could avail of the subsidy up until 31 October 2025.   Record investment in Apprenticeships, Skills and Research:   • In budget 2026, I allocated a record €79 million investment in apprenticeships – funding has more than doubled since 2020, rising from €184 million to over €400 million by 2026.  • Increase in the Research and Development Tax Credit from 30% to 35% – demonstrating our commitment to the research sector, promoting collaboration between industry and academia, and positioning ourselves as a competitive destination for innovative companies and startups.   Working towards Funding Reform   • In the area of funding reform, an HEA-led sectoral working group has been established and first two meetings held, with my Department to attend the group in an advisory capacity. The group will meet for two years, delivering an interim report next summer and final recommendations in 2027.   Building Confidence and Trust   • Quality and Qualifications Ireland (QQI), an agency under the remit of my Department, is currently introducing TrustEd Ireland – a new international education quality mark. TrustEd Ireland is a key pillar of the Government’s policy for international education, as set out in Global Citizens 2030: Ireland’s International Talent and Innovation Strategy to 2030. The TrustEd Ireland Mark will be awarded by QQI to higher education and English language education providers who have demonstrated that they meet new national standards to ensure a quality experience for international learners.   Higher Education Infrastructure   • My Department works collaboratively, through the HEA and higher education institutions, on the development and delivery of capital infrastructure projects. Almost €255m in capital funding was disbursed to the higher education sector during the course of 2025 to progress existing capital projects and support devolved funding mechanisms.  • As part of the National Development Plan 2025 review, I secured a capital allocation of €4.55bn over the next 5-years 2026 - 2030 for DFHERIS. Over half of this allocation €2.45 billion is targeted at strengthening Ireland’s research and Innovation capacity; this investment will support world-class research facilities, new research centres, advanced equipment and major international collaborations, while also enabling the continued delivery of significant investment in higher and further education.  • In November 2025 I announced INSPIRE, a landmark €750m research infrastructure programme for Ireland’s research and innovation system. It will support Ireland’s High-Performance Computing capacity and Tyndall National Institute. At least €500m will be invested over the lifetime of the NDP in two funding streams:  • Local institutional infrastructure, routine research equipment used within higher education institution for both teaching and research purposes, and  • Shared advanced infrastructures, major equipment that is appropriately shared across a number of institutions and is accessible to external users.  • This programme will be administered by the HEA and Research Ireland, and it will open for applications in Q1 2026.   My Priorities for 2026:Continued support for Technological Universities   • Support the implementation of the Targeted Enhancement Fund and in particular the first phase of Professorships in the Technological University sector.  • Support continued reform of academic staffing in the Technological University sector as recommended in the 2022 OECD report.   Generation investments in Research Infrastructure   • €2.1 billion will be provided for the development and enhancement of higher and further education infrastructure over the period 2026 to 2030. Of this, DFHERIS will have a total capital allocation of €311m in 2026, for further and higher education capital infrastructure investment. A programmatic approach to capital investment ensures strategic delivery of multiple projects as cohesive programmes, aligned with Infrastructure Guidelines. This investment will deliver new and upgraded facilities, modernised campuses with modern equipment and additional capacity to meet growing regional and national demand, focusing on a range of key higher and further education programmes. Specifically on the higher education side, it will focus on key higher education programmes, including, the Higher Education Strategic Infrastructure Programme, the Infrastructure Upgrade and Refurbishment Programme, the Technological Sector Strategic Projects Programme and the Public Private Partnership Programme.   Continued Expansion of places in Healthcare Education   • Over 1,100 additional healthcare course places will be created - backed by a €23.5 million investment, this major expansion includes medicine, nursing, disability therapies and social care - a 27% increase in capacity to train the next generation of healthcare professionals.   Strong focus on Inclusion and Wellbeing on Higher Education Campus   • €1 million in Budget 2026 for student mental health and healthy campus initiatives - supporting wellbeing across higher education institutions.  • €3 million boost for students with disabilities - includes €1 million for higher education and €2 million for further education and training colleges – supporting over 22,000 students and building a more inclusive education system. Included in the additional funding for further education and training is the provision to cover transport costs for learners with intellectual disabilities. This is part of our wider commitment to building a more inclusive and accessible education system.  • Ensuring that students are able to access quality information about their course, attendant qualifications and career prospects.
question.showAs: 779. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science the measures taken to support the higher education sector during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73564/25]

780. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science the measures taken to support the further education sector during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73565/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science  A key achievement in 2025 was the delivery of additional purpose-built student accommodation under the Short-Term Activation Programme. Through robust due diligence and value-for-money assessments, investment decisions were refined to ensure sustainability, resulting in 967 additional student beds either delivered or actively progressing by year-end.  Significant institutional milestones were achieved, with Maynooth University completing a 116-bed project, University College Dublin advancing a 493-bed development with approval to proceed to construction in September 2025, and Trinity College Dublin progressing its project. Together, these projects will deliver meaningful short-term accommodation capacity in high-demand locations.  The decision not to proceed with the Dublin City University 405-bed project further demonstrated strong governance and a commitment to ensuring all developments meet cost and value-for-money standards. Parallel progress was achieved through the Technological Sector Student Accommodation Programme (TSSAP), which is laying the foundations for longer-term, regionally balanced delivery. Phase 1 of the programme, completed in 2025, generated 53 strategic proposals from Technological Universities nationwide. These proposals now inform Phase 2, which is developing preliminary business cases, including financial and operational models, to ensure future projects are evidence-based, financially viable, and aligned with local student demand. 2025 also saw positive outcomes from targeted student supports.  The Student Accommodation Assistance Scheme, funded through Dormant Accounts, continued to support Traveller, Roma, and care-experienced students to access and remain in higher education. In the 2024/25 academic year, 29 students graduated, including two who progressed to Master’s programmes, while 47 students continued on their courses. These outcomes underline the tangible impact of targeted accommodation support on student retention, progression, and success.  The Student Accommodation Strategy (2025- 2035) will be brought to Government in the coming weeks, The strategy sets out a clear vision to improve access to higher education by addressing accommodation affordability and viability. Through targeted student supports and accelerated delivery of purpose-built student accommodation, it removes barriers to participation, supports student aspirations, and strengthens Ireland’s knowledge economy. Collaboration with higher education institutions, developers, and Government partners will enable a sustainable, inclusive approach that supports long-term economic growth.
question.showAs: 781. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science the measures taken to support and expand student accommodation during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73566/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science  My Department remains firmly committed to expanding apprenticeship opportunities as a central part of Ireland’s skills strategy. The Government invested €79 million through Budget 2026, bringing the total apprenticeship budget to over €410 million, more than double the level in 2020. In addition, I recently announced €20.5 million to fund the delivery of 99 craft training blocks and 8 consortium-led equipment projects, creating almost 1,600 additional apprenticeship places, many in construction-related trades.  The range of programmes has grown significantly, increasing from 54 in 2020 to 78 by the end of 2025. These now include areas such as Digital Marketing, Wind Turbine Maintenance, and Advanced Manufacturing Engineering. In October, I launched the Level 8 Accounting Technologist apprenticeship alongside the Taoiseach, the Tánaiste, Minister Lawless, and the Minister for the Economy in Northern Ireland. This is the first apprenticeship developed on an all-island basis, and it was designed specifically to respond to the impact of digitisation on the accounting profession. Building on this progress, next year I will launch the Action Plan for Apprenticeship 2026–2030, setting a target to increase annual apprentice registrations from 9,352 in 2024 to 12,500 by 2030, with two-thirds in craft and construction-related areas. My department will also continue to promote the value and visibility of apprenticeships through initiatives such as WorldSkills Ireland and the annual Apprentice of the Year and Apprentice Employer of the Year awards.
question.showAs: 782. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science the measures taken to enhance and expand apprenticeships during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73567/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science  In 2025, I continued to realise the ambitions laid out in the Programme for Government and the Impact 2030 Strategy, with a view to securing Ireland’s future prosperity, our wellbeing and our ability to compete globally as a small, advanced knowledge-based economy. This year we made significant progress towards acquiring a new national high-performance supercomputer, CASPIr, to be hosted by the University of Galway. 2026 will see the acquisition of this new national research resource. Once operational, CASPIr will benefit stakeholders across the broad spectrum of Ireland’s research and innovation ecosystem. In June, I signed the European Quantum Pact, joining other EU Member States in committing to the development of a world-class quantum technology ecosystem. This complements Ireland’s existing national strategy, Quantum 2030, which recognises the importance of fundamental research in quantum science and technology, talent development, international engagement and industry developments. An expert group, drawn from academia, industry, and the public sector has been established to implement Ireland’s quantum strategy.  In 2026, my Department will coordinate and support Ireland’s quantum technology initiatives in alignment with Europe’s growing quantum technology ecosystem. October saw the finalisation of a significant piece of work which saw Ireland join CERN as an Associate Member State, providing opportunity for our research community and Irish enterprises to access contracts and engage in knowledge transfer activity with this world leading research and engineering site. In November, I announced funding of over €3.5 million for 16 research projects under Research Ireland’s COALESCE (Collaborative Alliances for Societal Challenges) programme. This supports excellent, interdisciplinary research that addresses national and global societal challenges by fostering collaboration between researchers and policymakers, civil society, and enterprise. Also in November, I announced €34.5 million in funding for Research Ireland’s Frontiers for the Future Programme. This supports 39 cutting-edge research projects spanning 12 research institutions, investing in cutting-edge, curiosity-driven research and empowering individual researchers in the exploration of high-risk, high-reward ideas.  This year the programme was co-funded by the Children’s Health Foundation, Breakthrough Cancer Research, and the Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland and will be supporting 66 PhD students, 47 postdoctoral researchers, and 13 other research positions.Three new Research Ireland Accelerating Research to Commercialisation (ARC) Hubs were launched this year – the ARC Hub for Therapeutics (led by TCD), the ARC Hub for ICT (led by TUD) and the ARC Hub for HealthTech (led by University of Galway). These are supported by €98m co-funded by the Government of Ireland and the European Union under two European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) Programmes - the Southern, Eastern and Midland Regional Programme 2021-2027 and the Northern and Western Regional Programme 2021-2027. The ARC Hubs drive regional development by accelerating novel, cutting-edge research, towards commercial impact readiness, in areas aligned with Ireland’s Smart Specialisation Strategy for Innovation 2022-2027 and respective regional strategic priorities.  In December, I was proud to launch INSPIRE, a transformative €750 million investment in research infrastructure equipment – the largest in the history of the State. This programme will deliver cutting-edge equipment to our universities and attract world-class talent, cementing Ireland’s position as a global leader in research and innovation. Backed by the recent €4.55 billion capital allocation to my Department under the National Development Plan, INSPIRE will invest €750 million between 2026 and 2031, starting with €100 million in 2026, aligned with priorities such as competitiveness, digitalisation, and decarbonisation. Launched in September, the Action Plan for Competitiveness and Productivity recognises the centrality of research and innovation to Ireland's future economic performance.  My Department together with its agencies, Taighde Éireann – Research Ireland and the Higher Education Authority (HEA), are working with the higher education institutions and Enterprise Ireland to ensure that commercialisation opportunities for researchers are valued and incentivised in terms of academic progression. Ireland’s competitiveness depends on our ability to adapt. In 2026 I will continue to strengthen tertiary education, training, and research to build a sustainable, vibrant society. We want our citizens to be provided with the education that they need to succeed in today's world, and that is why we are aligning our skills offering with modern needs to ensure Ireland remains competitive in a rapidly evolving world.  The National Training Fund is central to this mission and enables us to invest in upskilling, reskilling, and lifelong learning to meet the demands of digitalisation, technological change, and the green transition. Through the Further Education and Training sector, we deliver flexible, industry-aligned micro-qualifications that respond quickly to emerging needs. The legislation to unlock the National Training Fund to enable this provision is nearing completion, and this work will continue across next year.Technology and labour markets are evolving rapidly. Government, through partnerships like the National Skills Council and Regional Skills Fora, is committed to ensuring access to high-quality learning for all. Guided by real-time insights from enterprise, we will continue driving this agenda because skills are the foundation of growth.  Through the continued implementation of Impact 2030: Ireland's Research and Innovation Strategy, we are strengthening our national research system to drive excellence and foster innovation. This whole-of-government approach is enhancing Ireland’s capacity at both researcher and institutional levels, through targeted actions on infrastructure, skills development and career pathways. These measures will assist researchers to conduct, manage, disseminate and apply their work more effectively. Impact 2030 also emphasises the vital role of talent and diversity in building and sustaining a dynamic Irish research and innovation ecosystem.  Earlier this year, through Taighde Éireann – Research Ireland, I was pleased to launch the Global Talent Ireland initiative. This capacity building measure is designed to bring the brightest minds from around the world to our universities and public research bodies. The programme will begin with a preliminary budget of €8 million per year and will be complementary to our broader commitment under Impact 2030 to strengthen and support Irish research and innovation, in this increasingly competitive global landscape.These strategic investments reflect Government’s unwavering commitment to talent, innovation, and opportunity, ensuring Ireland thrives in the decades ahead.
question.showAs: 783. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science the measures taken to boost Ireland’s research capacity during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73568/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science  I am conscious of financial challenges facing students and the need for the progressive implementation of measures to address costs as a barrier to education. It is a priority for me to explore the most effective and sustainable ways to support students in managing the cost of education. I also recognise that costs are not limited to fees. Students encounter additional expenses such as fuel, food, and accommodation, as well as specific course-related costs like books and materials.  Financial supports, such as the Free Fees Initiative and the SUSI student grant scheme are critical to supporting learners. In recent Budgets we have made significant improvements to the support framework. This has included restoration of SUSI Postgraduate supports and a new Part-Time Fee Scheme for Specified Undergraduate Courses. Students this academic year are also benefiting from the Budget 2025 decision to increase all income thresholds to avail of a student grant including increasing all standard rate thresholds by at least 15%.We have made further improvements in Budget 2026. For this academic year I have permanently reduced the Student Contribution charge by €500. This is the first such reduction since the scheme's introduction in 1995. It is expected to benefit around 108,000 undergraduate students with a further 14,000 apprentices benefitting from a 17% pro-rata reduction in their fees.  Other Budget 2026 SUSI measures include:  • An increase in the income threshold for the €500 student contribution grant form €115,000 to €120,000 from next year;  • Increases of €200–€430 in the maintenance grant rates; and  • A €500 increase in the postgraduate fee grant.  These changes are meaningful steps toward a fairer, more affordable system.I am conscious that not all students may avail of fee or grant supports. Last week, I announced that there will be €19.35m available under the Student Assistance Fund in the 2025/26 academic year. The funding includes €9.1m in core funding and additional funding of over €10.2m. This funding will benefit the most vulnerable students, who may be struggling with financial costs associated with attending college. Looking ahead to future Budget decisions, I will continue to consider all options available to me to reduce the cost of education for students and their families.
question.showAs: 784. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science the measures taken to make higher education more affordable during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73569/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment  Protecting our environment remains a key priority for the Government. My Department is responsible for setting the policy and legislative framework within which the key environmental regulators, including the Environmental Protection Agency and the local authorities, discharge their functions.  The EPA noted in the 2025 Industrial and Waste Licence Enforcement Summary Report (www.epa.ie/publications/compliance--enforcement/licensees/performance/FINAL-2024-EPA-Industrial-Waste-Licence-Enforcement-Summary-Report.pdf) that 1,309 inspections of industrial and waste facilities were carried out in the previous year and that 96% of such inspections which were unannounced.  The Environment (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 2025 was published in August 2025 and has completed Dáil Éireann, Third Stage. The proposals in the Bill aim to facilitate:  • the timely development of critical infrastructure in the energy sector, which will facilitate the transition to renewables;  • the deployment of better emissions abatement and other progressive environmental protection technologies which require amendments to licences; and  • securing of investment in infrastructure (including circular economy infrastructure) which will in turn stimulate significant sustainable economic activity within a well-regulated environmental licensing regime.  The EPA also noted in the Local Authority Environmental Enforcement Performance Report 2024 (www.epa.ie/publications/compliance--enforcement/public-authorities/Local-Authority-Environmental-Enforcement-Performance-Report-2024.pdf) that local authorities improved their environmental enforcement performance by 20% over the past three years, with 79% of the National Enforcement Priority (NEP) assessments meeting the required standard in 2024.  A key priority for 2026 is the progression of the Environment (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 2025 and the development of the supporting secondary legislation as well as the transposition of the revised Industrial Emissions Directive.  In relation to air quality, the 2025 progress report on the implementation of Ireland’s Clean Air Strategy noted that Ireland is compliant with all current EU ambient air quality standards and that Ireland came back into compliance with the National Emissions Reduction Commitment Directive (NECD) during 2023. The Air Pollution (Amendment) Bill was published in July 2025 and has completed Seanad Éireann, Second Stage. This Bill aims to further support enforcement action by the local authorities to protect our air quality and improve the registration and compliance systems in relation to the commercial sale and supply of solid fuels. As Minister, my priorities for 2026 include: progressing the Air Pollution (Amendment) Bill 2025 and the development of the supporting secondary legislation; transposing the revised EU Ambient Air Quality Directive; and accelerating pollutant emissions reductions through the further implementation of the Clean Air Strategy.  In relation to the circular economy, the Deposit and Return Scheme has collected over 2 billion containers since its introduction in February 2024, achieving an average return rate of 76%. Circular economy priorities for 2026 include:  • Transposition and implementation of EU circular economy legislation applying to textiles, packaging, batteries, plastic pellets and end of life vehicles.  • Supporting further progress in establishing Ireland’s Deposit and Return Scheme.  • Supporting the installation of a further 84 public drinking water fountains.  • Ensuring the efficient and effective delivery of producer responsibility obligations under EU and national law for the following material streams: packaging, batteries, waste electronic and electrical equipment, tyres, end-of-life vehicles, farm plastics, items containing plastics such as tobacco products and fishing gear.
question.showAs: 110. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment the key measures taken to enhance environmental protection during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73128/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment  This Government is committed to delivering measures and actions to achieve Ireland’s national and EU targets and ultimately climate neutrality by 2050. The Environmental Protection Agency's recent reporting confirms that Ireland’s overall GHG emissions reduced for a third consecutive year, and are now at their lowest level in 35 years.  Under the Climate Action Plan 2025 (CAP), and previous CAPs, there is an extensive programme of policies and measures that aim to achieve significant progress towards emission reductions with notable progress as follows:  • Ireland currently has 7.7 GW of renewable generation capacity. New records were broken in 2025 as Ireland reached 7 GW of renewable generation, 5 GW of wind generation, and 2 GW of solar PV generation for the first time. Renewables provided 41.1% of our electricity demand in 2024.  • On solar, 155,000 homes received grants to install rooftop solar, and free solar panels have been provided to 2,000 schools across Ireland to date.  • To end November this year, over 52,416 upgrades have been completed across SEAI’s residential and community energy upgrade schemes representing sustained and significant increases on the same period in each year since 2020.  • Private wires legislation is advancing to facilitate private sector investment in the grid and in renewable energy.  In 2026, progress will continue supported by:  • The Offshore Wind Delivery Taskforce (OWDT), led by me as Minister and including 16 Government Departments and State Agencies, will work together to deliver our offshore ambitions.  • Extensive grid investment overseen by the CRU, projected at almost €19 billion for the 2026-2030 period, will support the renewables led energy transformation.  • Budget 2026 includes a record capital allocation of €558 million from carbon tax revenue for the SEAI residential and community energy upgrade schemes. This is an €89 million increase on the corresponding Budget 2025 allocation. This funding is expected to be further supplemented with additional funding from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF).  • The governance arrangements for the Climate Action Plan Programme Board will continue to be strengthened.
question.showAs: 111. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment the key measures taken on climate action during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73129/25]

question.answerText: Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment  The key measures which have been taken to enhance energy security and production capacity during 2025 as well as actions for each year up to 2030 are outlined in the Energy Security in Ireland to 2030 report which  was published in November 2023.  This report outlines a strategy to ensure energy security in Ireland for this decade, while also ensuring a sustainable transition to a carbon neutral energy system by 2050.  The report was published as part of an Energy Security Package, containing a range of supplementary analyses, consultations, and reviews, which have informed the recommendations and actions related to energy security.  The 28 actions outlined in Energy Security in Ireland to 2030 are overseen by the Energy Security Group (ESG), which is chaired by the Secretary General of my Department and attended by officials from relevant Government Departments and Agencies. My priority for 2026 is to see all outstanding actions progressed and timelines adhered to.  The table at the link below provides an update of the actions to end Q3 2025.   Actions on Energy Security
question.showAs: 112. Deputy Seán Ó Fearghaíl asked the Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment the key measures taken on enhance energy security and production capacity during 2025; his priorities for 2026; and if he will make a statement on the matter. [73130/25]
